Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in a conference on Homological Mirror Symmetry held at the University of Miami from January 26 through January 31, 2015. Mirror symmetry originated in physics as a duality between superconformal quantum field theories. Maxim Kontsevich interpreted this duality in a consistent, powerful mathematical framework called Homological Mirror Symmetry (HMS). The ideas put forth by Kontsevich have led to dramatic developments in how the mathematical community approaches ideas from theoretical physics, and indeed our conception of space itself. Several cutting edge developments have happened in the last year.

The conference on Homological Mirror Symmetry at the University of Miami will serve as a perfect opportunity for a dissemination of these developments and encouragement of a wave of young, early career researchers in this subject area. The wide range of topics appearing in HMS research necessitates venues for the open exchanges of ideas in order for graduate students and early-career researchers to stay informed on current topics. The subject has developed extremely rapidly in recent years, and this conference will have an immense broader impact by bringing young people into it. More details on the conference can be found at https://math.berkeley.edu/~auroux/miami2015.html.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This is the  report on NSF DMS-1502578  HOMOLOGICAL MIRROR SYMMETRY CONFERENCE MIAMI 2015.

Let us recall  that Mirror symmetry originated in physics as a duality between $N= 2$ superconformal quantum
field theories.  In 1990,
Maxim Kontsevich, interpreted this duality in a consistent, powerful mathematical framework called Homological Mirror Symmetry (HMS). The ideas put forth by Kontsevich in his Fields medal and ICM addresses have led to dramatic
developments in how the mathematical community approaches ideas from theoretical physics, and indeed our conception of space itself. These developments created a frenzy of activity in the mathematical community which has led to a remarkable synergy of diverse mathematical disciplines, notably symplectic geometry, algebraic geometry, and category
theory.  HMS is now the foundation of a wide range of contemporary mathematical research dedicated to the ideas initiated and continually refined by the principal investigator. This has attracted many distinguished senior researchers, and continues to draw much early-career talent, among whom we note: M. Ballard, C. Diemer, T. Dyckerhoff,  D. Favero, U. Isik, G. Kerr, P. Pandit, A. Preygel, and N. Sheridan. 


Numerous works by a range of authors have demonstrated the interaction of mirror symmetry and HMS with a wide range of new and subtle mathematical structures. We note in particular methods from Lagrangian intersection
Floer theory, integrable systems and wall-crossing, derived and higher categories, and non-commutative Hodge
structures, each of which are of immense independent mathematical interest, and each of which are intimately connected with HMS. Such connections have established HMS as a dominating force in modern geometry. The theory of Gaps and Spectra is one of the most spectacular achievements of HMS.

 The exchanges have been greatly facilitated and accelerated by
several conferences
 
 
 
 1) Two  workshop in Miami January  2015,
January 2015. During this workshop  shprt courses were given  by Voisin, Seidel, Moore  and Kontsevich. They   surveyed the recent developments in the subject.
In addition we have had lectures by Corti, Efimov, Pantev, Abouzaid, Fukaya, Keating, Ganatra, Luntz,
Goncharov, Soibelman, Kapranov, Perutz, Kaledin.

Special consideration was give to underrepresented groups - Voisin, Keating, Lee, Park, Gasparim  and young people
- Efimov, Keating, Ganatra, Perutz. More than 60 scientists participated.


The funds were mainly used to support students and postdocs.


2) Series of conferences -  Vienna, Moscow, UPenn, UCBerkeley  were organized
in collaboration with the M-center KSU, LGA Moscow. These confernces  gave
opportunities  for an interchange of ideas between Hodge theorists,
string theorists and tropical geometers. These all  have  helped
crystalize ideas of combining wall crossing, algebraic cycles and
spectra into a coherent theory, one that has given a fresh
mathematical input into modern physics. We plan to build on this
in the future. All these have helped established Vienna as a major center for HMS.

A very strong connection with physics and theory of dynamical systems was established.
The short course by G. Moore help developing this interaction to a new level.
 It has   helped ideas of wall crossing, algebraic cycles and spectra crystalize and gave back our dues to Physics.
